awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Communications in Ultra-Low-Rate Regime: Fundamental Limits, Code Constructions, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless networks have become an integral part of our society by connecting billions of users around the globe. The next generation wireless networks, known as 5G, are expected to deliver orders of magnitude higher data rates to an ever-increasing number of devices. The fundamental limits on how much networks can be pushed towards these advancements are determined by the amount of available wireless bands. To this end, two extremes of wireless communications have become increasingly important, namely, narrowband and wideband. The narrowband communication, using a small band of frequencies, enables connectivity of thousands of devices, such as everyday objects in Internet-of-Things (IoT) networks, to a single cell tower. Wideband communications, using large swaths of frequencies, at extremely high frequencies is the key enabling technology for delivering ultra-high data rates to 5G mobile users. In both of these scenarios, individual bits of information are assigned extremely low power for communication resulting in bit-wise wireless channels with low capacity. This introduces a new array of fundamental problems with respect to communications over low-capacity channels that is the focus of this project. The results of this project will contribute to the foundation of information and coding theory as well as the development of wireless networks that can achieve the ultimate limits of narrowband and wideband communications.

Recently, the wireless standards entity, 3GPP, has introduced new protocols into the standard in order to integrate IoT into the cellular network. A major feature of these protocols is to deploy ultra-low-rate communications in order to address diverse requirements of IoT networks. Such low-rate communication is enabled in the standard by simply allowing a large number of block repetitions, which could be extremely suboptimal from the channel coding perspective. A similar situation arises in wideband scenarios. Wideband channels can essentially provide high data rates, in terms of bits per second. However, individual coded bits experience extremely low signal-to-noise ratios, due to limited signal power and larger attenuations in higher frequencies. In light of the emerging applications in these two extremes of wireless communications, the investigators aim at a comprehensive investigation of channel coding in the low-capacity regime. The specific objectives in this project are as follows: (1) Provide a precise framework for channel coding at low capacity, and characterize fundamental non-asymptotic laws for channel coding in this regime; (2)  Develop techniques for the non-asymptotic analysis of wireless wideband and millimeter wave systems; (3) Investigate state-of-the-art codes, including their construction, performance, and efficient decoding, for adaptation to low-rate regimes; (4) Construct efficient concatenated coding schemes including coded repetition and concatenation with low-rate algebraic codes, given diverse requirements of low-capacity applications. Consequently, this project develops a formal connection between information theory, coding theory, and wireless communications resulting in a mathematically precise interface between these areas to address the challenges of narrowband and wideband wireless systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Digital communication technologies have become a vital part of our daily lives, impacting various aspects of society, from personal communication over cellular phones to the global communication networks connecting individuals and businesses worldwide. All digital communication technologies are essentially built upon fundamental information-theoretic concepts. This includes understanding the fundamental limits of data rate as well as practical methods to enable the reliable communication of binary bits in the presence of inherent noises in the systems. More specifically, error-correcting codes are among the fundamental blocks of any digital communication system rendering reliable communication a possibility. Furthermore, advancements in the field of coding theory, a field that studies error-correcting codes, have been a major driving force in the evolution of communication technologies. Currently, 5G systems are being deployed across the globe with new features being introduced into the standard with every new release, while discussions on 6G are already underway. The next generation 5G/6G systems will deliver fiber-like 20Gb/s for reliable communication of enormous amounts of data and will deliver coverage to a massive number of users, or what is referred to as the Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices. To this end, deploying protocols in challenging scenarios of wireless communications, in terms of the available frequency band, in narrowband communication for IoT networks, or in terms of the available power for ultra-low-power IoT devices are becoming increasingly important. In this project, we focused on addressing and solving problems related to low-power and low-rate communication. This includes understanding and characterizing the fundamental limits on what is achievable, in terms of communication rate or measure of reliability, as well as constructing practical error-correcting codes approaching these limits in the low-power and low-rate regimes.

Next, we provide a summary of our main technical findings.

We provided a precise mathematical formulation of low-rate communication channels, a scenario referred to as low-capacity channels, from a non-asymptotic analysis perspective. Herein, asymptotic means the length of the code block goes to infinity. However, we opted to focus on finite block lengths relevant for practical purposes. We then observed that channel variations in the low-capacity regime may be better approximated by different probabilistic laws rather than the ones used for channels with moderate capacity. We coupled this observation with other approximation methods and sharp bounds on the tails of underlying probability distributions to provide tight lower and upper bounds on what is fundamentally achievable in low-capacity channels. We further developed new channel coding schemes, including efficient encoding and decoding algorithms, based on sophisticated concatenated designs suitable for low-rate regimes, and characterized their performance under various practical communication channels in the low-rate regime. In another direction, we aimed to understand another fundamental parameter of codes, namely, the minimum distance, in low-rate regimes. The minimum distance of a code governs the guarantees on its error-correction capability. We derived new upper and lower bounds on the rate, given a certain high minimum distance, which corresponds to the low-rate regime.  

In another major direction, we explored low-rate coding and communication for security and privacy. For instance, low-rate communications naturally gain relevance in covert settings where the aim is to hide the existence of communications from an adversary. In particular, we considered covert communications over millimeter-wave (mmWave) bands, where a mmWave transmitter attempts to reliably communicate to a receiver, while hiding the existence of communication from an adversary. We then characterized the optimal covert rate that can be achieved using the proposed setup. In another work in this direction, we proposed to efficiently utilize available physical layer functions, such as encoders and decoders, to provide security as well as reliability, introducing a novel threshold-type security criterion. Then constructions of threshold-secure codes are proposed that are based on readily available linear block codes. Continuing in this direction, we explored applications of low-rate codes to provide security and privacy in large-scale computation. In particular, we constructed and analyzed secure coded regression schemes in the context of distributed computation over multiple low-cost low-power computational nodes. We further developed a new method, referred to as coded machine unlearning, to address concerns regarding the right to be forgotten in learning applications using random low-rate codes.

Finally, we designed novel strategies for multiple-access communication, where multiple users are communicating with a single receiver simultaneously, with a particular focus on low-capacity applications. The new designs result from Kronecker products of a sequence of matrices. These designs are then used to scale the resource assignment to a large number of users. We demonstrated that the proposed schemes are particularly beneficial in low-capacity regimes which are important in practical scenarios of utmost interest such as the IoT and massive machine-type communication.
